title: Trobriand Islands rain forests
text:
The Trobriand Islands rain forests are a <a href="tropical%20and%20subtropical%20moist%20broadleaf%20forests">tropical moist broadleaf forest</a> <a href="ecoregion">ecoregion</a> of southeastern <a href="Papua%20New%20Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a>.
 
The islands of this ecoregion have been separated from mainland New Guinea since the <a href="Late%20Pleistocene">Late Pleistocene</a>, and much of the biota is unique, including four mammal species and two birds-of-paradise plant species. The ecoregion covers .
Geography.
The ecoregion includes several island groups lying east of the eastern peninsula of the island of <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a>, within <a href="Milne%20Bay%20Province">Milne Bay Province</a>, including the <a href="d%27Entrecasteaux%20Islands">d'Entrecasteaux Islands</a> and <a href="Trobriand%20Islands">Trobriand Islands</a> archipelagoes, and <a href="Woodlark%20Island">Woodlark Island</a>. The largest portion of the ecoregion and the nearest to the New Guinea mainland is made up of three principal islands of the d'Entrecasteaux group: <a href="Goodenough%20Island">Goodenough Island</a>, <a href="Fergusson%20Island">Fergusson Island</a>, and <a href="Normanby%20Island%2C%20Papua%20New%20Guinea">Normanby Island</a>.
Flora.
The Trobriand Islands and Woodlark Island consist primarily of lowland rain forest on limestone substrates. Goodenough, Fergusson, and Normanby Islands consist mainly of lowland rain forest on acid soil.
The major rain forest tree genera include "Pometia, <a href="Octomeles">Octomeles</a>, <a href="Alstonia">Alstonia</a>, <a href="Campnosperma">Campnosperma</a>, <a href="Canarium">Canarium</a>, <a href="Dracontomelon">Dracontomelon</a>, <a href="Pterocymbium">Pterocymbium</a>, <a href="Cryptocarya">Cryptocarya</a>, <a href="Intsia">Intsia</a>, <a href="Ficus">Ficus</a>", and "<a href="Terminalia%20%28plant%29">Terminalia</a>".<br>
Tree species include:
Fauna.
Animal species native to the ecoregion include:
The ecoregion corresponds to the D'Entrecasteaux and Trobriand Islands <a href="endemic%20bird%20area">endemic bird area</a>. There are two endemic bird-of-paradise species, the <a href="curl-crested%20manucode">curl-crested manucode</a> ("Manucodia comrii") and <a href="Goldie%27s%20bird-of-paradise">Goldie's bird-of-paradise</a> ("Paradisaea decora").
Conservation and threats.
The main threats to the ecoregion include logging by foreign companies and conversion of habitat into agricultural lands.
